image.altText: A man wearing a white Tyvek suit and full face PAPR mask with HEPA filter collar poses face on for a photograph in a lab

props.synopsis: Three of Australia's leading COVID experts share their personal COVID safety strategies and reflect on what must happen if we're to blunt the growing health crisis the pandemic is causing — and prepare for the next one.

title.children: Scientist Brendan Crabb caught COVID after breaking his own rule. This is how he avoided it for so long

image.altText: Blue prints of wind turbines are laid over a picture of the ocean

props.synopsis: Offshore wind offers great promise for Australia, but the industry will have to win an information war to convince some towns to take it up.

title.children: For offshore wind to take off, it will first have to win an information war

image.altText: A little girl with a serious expression on her face

props.synopsis: Hiba used to live in a modern apartment building in southern Gaza, spending her days at school or playing with friends. Now, every day is a fight to survive to the next.

title.children: 'Even for death, you wait in line': How this little girl keeps herself alive in Gaza

image.altText: A male tennis player, wearing blue, holds his ear, gesturing to spectators to be loud

props.synopsis: Australian number one Alex de Minaur takes centre stage from the Australian Open champion, while world number one Iga Świątek succumbs to an unfortunate 45-year first. Here are five quick hits from day seven at Melbourne Park.

title.children: Five quick hits — de Minaur pushes Djokovic from prime time as Laver reveals who he's backing

image.altText: A man wearing a grey hoodie with pink writing stares off camera.

props.synopsis: As discussions surrounding menopause increasingly find their place in mainstream conversations, one healthcare worker is creating a podcast exploring what menopause is like for trans men and gender-diverse people.

title.children: For a transgender man going through menopause, Shane feels there aren't a lot of resources out there

image.altText: Sunbakers lie on a rock near the water with Sydney Harbour Bridge in the background

props.synopsis: Swimming in the harbour can make you sick and risk your life. Here's how to avoid it, and what experts say to do if you accidentally fall in.

title.children: For many, it's an unspoken rule to not swim in the middle of Sydney Harbour. But why is this the case?

image.altText: A man holding a thermometer and dressed in warm clothes frowns at the camera

props.synopsis: As temperatures plummet, Russia's dilapidated infrastructure is struggling to keep up. Heating is a major concern, with freezing residents taking to social media to vent about their "fight for survival".

title.children: Putin is facing a potential 'avalanche of disasters' at home. The timing couldn't be worse

image.altText: police car parked in front of flood waters in Brisbane 1974

props.synopsis: As a cyclone hovers menacingly off the Queensland Coast, the lessons learned five decades ago, again in 2011 and more recently in 2022 may be put to the test.

title.children: The $980 million flood catastrophe that changed Brisbane forever

image.altText: A man with a grey beard sits at an outdoor table, smiling at the camera.

props.synopsis: Struggling with life on the streets and looking after an aggressive dog, Mark turned to Pets in the Park for support. The service is experiencing an increase in demand as more Australians are forced into homelessness.

title.children: How free service for pet owners experiencing homelessness is making the world a better place

image.altText: A group of people help themselves to servings of a communal meal.

props.synopsis: Recently, 22 supermarket store managers were treated to a two-course meal prepared by a professional chef using only ingredients that could have ended up in the bin, in a bid to show how surplus food can be turned into healthy, delicious meals.

title.children: These Canberra supermarket workers are eating a meal using food they might have otherwise thrown away

image.altText: A woman with strawberry blonde hair smiles in a field of flowers.

props.synopsis: Determined for a better life for her children, a regional South Australian woman has gone from bankrupt to home owner. Kirsty experienced financial abuse, and wants others to know it is possible to rebuild their lives.

title.children: Leaving an abusive relationship sent Kirsty bankrupt. Now she's a home owner

image.altText: Alex de Minaur pumps his fist at the 2024 Australian Open.

props.synopsis: Pat Cash describes the public expectation on Australians playing at their home major as "crippling". This may prove to be Alex de Minaur's biggest challenge to keeping his tournament hopes alive, writes Luke Pentony.

title.children: Why de Minaur will need to conquer more than Rublev's forehand if he wants to make Aus Open quarterfinals

image.altText: A lightning bolt and purple grey skies, over sparse bushland in WA

props.synopsis: Over the past six months, Australia has gone from a parched landscape on the brink of extreme drought to flooding rains in summer. In the background, several climate drivers have been helping guide the weather.

title.children: Here's what's been pulling the strings on Australia's weather recently — and it's not just El Niño

image.altText: People gathered around building debris

props.synopsis: A series of reported strikes in Syrian capital Damascus killed five members of Iran's Revolutionary Guards, according to the group.

title.children: Five of Iran's Revolutionary Guards in Syria reportedly killed in air strikes

image.altText: Val Guseli leaps off the side of a half pipe

props.synopsis: Scotty James and teenager Val Guseli have scored a stunning 1-2 at the prestigious Laax snowboard half pipe event in Switzerland, as Jakara Anthony secures her seventh gold of the moguls season.

title.children: Scotty James and Val Guseli land historic Australian 1-2 in half pipe

image.altText: James Cromitie center led police officers Terror Sting

props.synopsis: A man convicted in 2010 of plotting to blow up New York City synagogues, a Jewish community centre and shoot down military planes, has been ordered to be released from prison by a judge who said the defendant was part of a group manipulated by the FBI.

title.children: US judge orders early release of 'hapless' petty criminal caught up in post-9/11 terror sting

image.altText: a green mango in the foreground and a man with a mango picker in the background

props.synopsis: It's a small-scale operation, but it brings a golden bounty. Henry Petersen reckons he's one of the last backyard pickers in north Queensland.

title.children: Battling green ants and falling through roofs, picking mangoes in backyards for 45 years has left Henry battered and bruised

image.altText: A group of femmes in colourful outfits and wigs, dance together in a burlesque-style onstage.

props.synopsis: Sydney is chock-full of art and culture right now, with festival shows being staged everywhere from the beach to basements to the best theatres. But how do you choose which to see? We've got some tips for you.

title.children: A Blak musical, a sitar virtuoso and highly camp cabaret are some of our favourite acts from Sydney Festival

image.altText: A middle-aged man in a black shirt, sitting.

props.synopsis: From searching for missing people in the outback to car crashes and drug smuggling investigations, Michael Potts has lived and worked through some of the most tumultuous yet pioneering years in NT Police history.

title.children: Much has changed since he joined the NT Police 40 years ago, but this officer's dedication has never wavered

image.altText: A boy sits and looks into the distance

props.synopsis: Cooper Symlie is an angler at heart. Despite a rare condition that causes painful reactions to stimuli such as water and air, he's relentless in his pursuit of the catch of the day.

title.children: Pint-sized fisherman tells tales of angling adventures and the world's most painful incurable condition

image.altText: Albanese, pictured at the bottom of the frame, looks up as he walks out of the house of reps

props.synopsis: The prime minister has called Labor MPs back to Canberra nearly two weeks early to discuss ways to ease the pressure on household budgets without adding to inflation.

title.children: All hands on deck as PM calls urgent caucus meeting to tackle cost-of-living crisis

image.altText: A photo of sheep  inside a pen

props.synopsis: The federal government orders a live export ship carrying thousands of Australian sheep and cattle to turn back after it was diverted due to the deteriorating security situation in the Middle East.

title.children: Stranded live export ship forced to return to Australia amid deteriorating Middle East security

image.altText: Charred windows after a school fire in China.

props.synopsis: Thirteen schoolchildren die in a dormitory fire in central China's Henan province, Chinese state media reports.

title.children: Fire in primary school dorm in central China kills 13 children

image.altText: Forum Theatre 1

props.synopsis: A line of people wrap around the century old building unaware parts of it weighing up to 60kg could collapse at any moment.

title.children: Parts of Melbourne's Forum Theatre at risk of collapse as concert goers wait for doors to open

image.altText: A man's arm with many blisters on it from fire ant bites

props.synopsis: A gardener has been attacked by fire ants after disturbing a nest at a flood pod village. The find has raised questions around how the ants were introduced into the area.

title.children: Blisters and pain as fire ant nest uncovered in NSW outbreak

image.altText: A screenshot from a video showing tops of trees in the foreground and a plane on fire in the sky in the background, at night

props.synopsis: Investigators say they found a tennis ball-sized hole above one of the plane's engines during a post-flight inspection.

title.children: 'We have an engine fire': Boeing plane's mid-air emergency caught on camera

subjects.title: Air and Space Accidents and Incidents

props.synopsis: Three men have been arrested after more than 40 guns, sophisticated explosive devices and $1 million in cash were seized across Melbourne.

title.children: Firearms, cash and explosives seized in Melbourne, three arrested including alleged Russian organised crime member

image.altText: 7-day cyclone forecast, January 18 2024

props.synopsis: The Bureau of Meteorology predicts the slow-moving system will track south or south-westerly over the weekend.

title.children: Cyclone 'more likely than not' will cross Queensland coast next week, possibility of severe category three system

image.altText: A police officer walking with a large package of drugs off a boat at a marina

props.synopsis: Two former drug detectives explain common methods for importing cocaine and why so much ends up in Australia's oceans.

title.children: Former detectives explain the likely reason cocaine worth tens of millions of dollars is washing onto NSW beaches

image.altText: A George Mason University fan holds up the cover of Sports Illustrated magazine.

props.synopsis: The jobs of people who produce Sports Illustrated have been left in limbo after the company that paid to maintain the iconic brand's print and digital products tells staff that its licence has been revoked.

title.children: Sports Illustrated magazine employees left in limbo two months on from AI scandal

image.altText: a woman holds a ring in both of her hands

props.synopsis: A police campaign raising awareness to human trafficking focuses on teachers, parents and fellow students as they're "often the first to see the signs" of forced marriage — the most common form of the crime.

title.children: Forced marriage cases spike across Australia as schools urged to help identify victims

image.altText: A man with dark hair and sunglasses.

props.synopsis: The search resumes for missing man Dan Cojocea, who was caught in a rip near Sleaford, south-west of Port Lincoln, on Friday afternoon.

title.children: Search resumes for missing man caught in a rip at SA beach

image.altText: Four women in blouses and black suits posing

props.synopsis: The lead singer of the 1960s girl group, best known for its tough image and hits such as Leader of the Pack and Give Him a Big Kiss, died on Friday, according to media reports.

title.children: Leader of the Pack and lead singer of the Shangri-Las, Mary Weiss, dies at age 75
